newsitem.title: CHINA: China power plant to start operation in 1999.
newsitem.headline: China power plant to start operation in 1999.

text.p: One of China's largest power plants will begin operation in 1999, with equipment supplied by a consortium led by Siemens AG and U.S. firm Foster Wheeler Corp, company officials said on Friday.

Siemens's power-generation division on Thursday signed a contract worth almost $720 million to help equip the $1.6 billion Yangcheng power plant in China's northern Shanxi province, a Siemens official said.
An earlier estimate putting the value of the plant at $2.0 billion probably included associated costs such as those of transmission, the official said.

Siemens would supply generators, control systems and other equipment worth around $360 million for the 2,100-megawatt plant, making it the German group's biggest power project in China, the official said.
The contract includes financing from Germany with an annual interest rate of about 6.6 percent, he said.
Foster Wheeler would supply boiler systems and other equipment worth around $358 million, to be financed with loans from the U.S. Export-Import Bank, he said.
The first unit of the plant was expected to go into operation in 1999, he said.

The Yangcheng plant, powered by six 350-megawatt generators, would supply electricity to the eastern coastal province of Jiangsu, as part of China's efforts to substitute coal transportation with electricity transmission, the China Daily newspaper said.
The Chinese unit of U.S. company AES would hold a 25 percent stake in the plant, with state investors from Shanxi and Jiangsu accounting for the rest, the Siemens official said.
